floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are falling in the lower Avon area and are now below the Flood Alert threshold. 
Further rain is expected this afternoon through to Sunday afternoon which may result in this Alert needing to be re-issued.
We will continue to monitor the situation closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of localised thunderstorms. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 06:00 tomorrow morning, 08/09/2024. 

Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. 

Thunderstorms are forecast between 21:00 on 07/09/24 and 18:00 on 08/09/24, with low confidence over exact timing and locations. We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday morning, 10/09/2024.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and never drive through flood water, just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.  

To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

This message will be updated by 15:00 tomorrow, 08/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Due to heavy rainfall forecast, flooding is possible overnight Saturday 7th September and into the early hours of Sunday 8th September in the area of Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries.
There may be flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers.
We expect the rivers to remain high throughout Sunday 8th September, though no flooding to properties is forecast, and flood warnings are not expected to be issued.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.
We are constantly monitoring river levels, and this message will be updated on Sunday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes

"Small, flashier rivers and streams may respond to heavy rainfall as a result of localised thunderstorms passing through the area.  This message has been issued pre-emptively ahead of localised thunderstorms between 21:00 on 07/09/24 and 18:00 on 08/09/24.  Given the unpredictable nature of thunderstorms, there is low confidence in the locations and impacts of rainfall at this point.  Areas most at risk are low lying agricultural land, roads and footpaths close to small rivers and streams.  Water levels could rise rapidly and potentially generate deep, fast flows.   
Thunderstorms and heavy rainfall are forecast over the next 24 hours, with low confidence over exact timing and locations.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 12:00 tomorrow, 08/09/24, or as the situation changes."

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday 8th of September. Over the last few days, we have seen prolonged heavy rainfall meaning catchments are becoming wetter, and the River Strat, River Neet and River Tamar are expected to rise in response to further rain forecast through Saturday evening, overnight and throughout Sunday.  

Expected river levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from around 6am. We expect rivers to continue to rise throughout Sunday, with levels peaking on Sunday evening. No flooding to properties is currently forecast.    

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. There may be standing water present for several days, please do not walk or drive through flood water as it is hazardous. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. 

This message will be updated by midday on Sunday 8th of September, or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hayle, Perrancoombe Stream, Bolingey Stream, Portreath Stream, Newlyn Coombe River

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday 8th of September. Over the last few days, we have seen prolonged heavy rainfall meaning catchments are becoming wetter, and rivers are expected to rise in response to further rain forecast through Saturday evening, overnight and throughout Sunday morning.   

Expected river levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from around 6am.  

We expect rivers to continue to rise throughout Sunday morning, with levels peaking by midday. No flooding to properties is currently forecast.     

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  There may be standing water present for several days, please do not walk or drive through flood water as it is hazardous. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages.   

This message will be updated by midday on Sunday 8th of September, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Camel, River Allen, Bodmin Town Leat, River Valency

items.message:
Flooding is possible on Sunday 8th of September. Over the last few days, we have seen prolonged heavy rainfall meaning catchments are becoming wetter, and in particular the Rivers Valency and Camel are expected to rise in response to further rain forecast through Saturday evening, overnight and throughout Sunday.  

Expected river levels suggest that there will be flooding to low lying land and roads close to rivers from around 6am. 

We expect rivers to continue to rise throughout Sunday, with levels peaking on Sunday evening. No flooding to properties is currently forecast.    

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  There may be standing water present for several days, please do not walk or drive through flood water as it is hazardous. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages.  

 This message will be updated by midday on Sunday 8th of September, or earlier if the situation changes.
